# Types and classes 
## Types
```{r}
typeof(1.5)
typeof("toto")
typeof('toto')
typeof(TRUE)
typeof(1L)
typeof(1)
typeof(typeof)
typeof(list())
```
You can't expand types, but you can create your own types (not in the same space, they don't have the hardware version). The developer creates classes, types are given by the environment. 

## Classes
```{r}
data(iris)
iris|>class()
iris|>typeof()
```
# Vectors

Many things in R are vectors (and most of other things are lists). A vector is a collection of values of the same type (possibly a single value)
```{r}
x<- 15.25
length(x) #all vectors have a length
x[1] #access to an element
typeof(x)
```

```{r}
y<-c(1,-2,45,1.5,-1e-10)
y
typeof(y)
y[2]
length(y)
```
The `c` function can be seen as a creation function or, more accurately, as a vector concatenation function 
```{r}
c(x,y)
```

# Indexing 

```{r}
x<-c(6,5,1,2,3,4)
x[3]
```

```{r}
x[4]<-15
x
```

Assignment can be understood has a value semantic assignment: `x` and `y` are different vectors with the same initial content. Therefore, modifying `x`has no effect on `y`. 

```{r}
y<-x
y
```
```{r}
x[1]<-18
x
y
```

```{r}
x
x[c(2,2,1,4,3)]
```
```{r}
x[0]
x[7]
x[10]
```

```{r}
typeof(numeric(0))
typeof(NA)
```


```{r}
typeof(NA_integer_)
NA_integer_
```

```{r}
x
x[c(4,1,0,15)]
```

```{r}
c(numeric(0),5,numeric(0))
```


```{r}
y<-c("A","B","C")
y
y[c(TRUE,FALSE,TRUE)]
```
```{r}
x
x[c(-1,-4)] #can't mix positive and negative values, use negative to remove an index
```

We can index by integer, in R everything is a vector
